WRITING.TITLE: having to clock out of work before my shift finishes, questions inside.
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey again, i posted a few days ago about a new job i got, and something has just been pointed out to me, i work at a pub, two days a week atm, and for example the weekend just gone fri-sat i was scheduled to do 10:30 hours over the two days, we closed an hour early on friday and i had to clock out, missing out on 1 hours wage, the same happened on saturday, but had to clock out 30minutes early, again missing out on 30min pay, is there anything i can do about this or is it legal? considering it costs me over an hours wage to get to work and back home, it's kind of frustrating to missing out on quite a bit of money
Thanks

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-3348869/Doctor-wife-sentenced-keeping-slave-24-years.html "Although their mistreatment of Mr Inuk spanned 24 years, illegal servitude only became an offence under the Coroners and Justice Act 2009 so they were convicted and sentenced for their actions only between 2010 and 2013. However, Judge Arran said he considered the total length of time Mr Inuk suffered as an aggravating feature." there was another post on reddit a while ago with the same kind of thing, it was also mentioned on QI, and i did about 6-7 years of Public services in school/college and this came up alot when talking about laws etc
I seem to recall it being a loophole in the law, if somebody owed u money you could basically keep them as indentured slaves until they payed it off if they had nowhere to live
Slavery in England, made illegal in 2010 if I recall

I've never really understood the stigma around people talking about pay, especially after watching the Adam Ruins everything bit on youtube about discussing pay, that definitely reinforced what i thought previously

Thank you, as soon as i heard her mention it in the contract before i signed it it instantly what can i say, was a bit shocked? i thought it a bit strange and was sure it wasnt right, always nice to know the law has your back

WRITING.TITLE: Can employers contractually stop employees from discussing pay?
WRITING.TEXT: Recently got a new job and in the contract i had to sign it said they discussing pay was against their terms of service? just wondering if they are legally able to actually inforce that
